intro: Silene graminifolia f. vulgaris, commonly known as the common green-stemmed catchfly, is a flowering plant characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, clustered flowers. It typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as fields and roadsides, preferring well-drained soils. The plant produces pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are linear and often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its showy, often brightly colored blooms.
